Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Lien-Yung Kao is " Thermodynamic formalism and its applications to deformation spaces." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Chicago, and the sponsoring scientist is Amie Wilkinson.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of dynamical systems was pioneered around the turn of the 20th Century by Henri Poincar and George Birkhoff. Since then, its development has been influenced by adjacent areas of mathematics (e.g., number theory, geometry, probability), and other natural sciences (e.g., celestial mechanics, statistical mechanics, population biology). The proposed project belongs to that rich tradition and focuses on deriving fundamental results for systems arising from geometry and topology, in particular, through a dynamics tool?thermodynamic formalism.

    With the same spirit of thermodynamics, thermodynamic formalism was introduced by Sinai, Ruelle, and Bowen in the 1970s as a tool for describing the behavior of large ensembles of trajectories and related dynamics objects such as entropy and equilibrium states. Entropy is a crucial number in dynamics that quantifies the dynamical complexity. Interestingly, in many cases, entropy captures the geometric features of the systems. Thermodynamic formalism intertwines dynamical and geometrical perspectives of entropy and other dynamics quantities. Hence, it becomes a convenient tool for understanding dynamics and geometry. 

    Many proposed problems are completed and match with the expectations. In what follows, the outcomes of the project in intellectual merit and broader impact.

Intellectual merit

The proposed project concerns applying dynamics tools to study geometry and topology problems. Especially using entropy, a dynamics quantity, to reveal the geometry of the ambient space, so-called entropy rigidity. On top of the, using entropy rigidity to study the shape of deformations spaces of surfaces. 

    Many results are known in this direction when the surface is closed. During this project, the PI successfully generalized these results to surfaces with punctures. Despite the non-compactness causes many issues in the analysis, most of the entropy rigidity phenomena stand in the non-compact and higher-rank deformation spaces.  

    During the fellowship, the PI started another related project study geometrical non-uniformly hyperbolic systems. Non-uniformly hyperbolic refers to that the rate of the spreading of orbits is not uniform. This speed depends on the shape of the manifolds. For example, for manifolds is compact with negative sectional curvature, then the spreading rate of geodesic has a uniform control. This non-uniform behavior causes many challenges. Nevertheless, using the Riemannian geometry, the PI was able to show the uniqueness of a special measure, the equilibrium states, for manifolds without focal points. 

Broader Impact 

During the fellowship, the PI worked on increasing and stimulating the communication between the US and Taiwanese mathematic communities. The PI spent several weeks in Taiwan and gave several talks and mini-courses to introduce ergodic geometry to the Taiwanese mathematics community. The PI also helped to organize and to invite world-leading scholars to visit and speak in Taiwan.  

    Moreover, the PI advised and talked to several talented students in Taiwan and encouraged them to visit and or study in the US. 

    Base on the communication channel the PI proposed, many math interactions has started. The strength of mathematics in Taiwan is geometry. Ergodic geometry is a new field in relating geometry and dynamics. There will be much fruitful development if the US's dynamicists and geometers in Taiwan can continue their communication.
